required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Long-Term Safety Study of Org 50081 (Esmirtazapine) in Elderly Outpatients With Chronic Primary Insomnia (176005/P05697/MK-8265-001)
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Long-Term Safety Study of Org 50081 in Elderly Outpatients With Chronic Primary Insomnia Examining the Effects of 1.5 mg or 3.0 mg of Org 50081

brief_summary.textblock: The current study is a 52-week safety study in elderly outpatients with chronic primary insomnia randomized to treatment with 1.5 mg or 3.0 mg of esmirtazapine (Org 50081, SCH 900265, MK-8265) to investigate the safety and tolerability of long-term treatment with esmirtazapine in elderly patients.

detailed_description.textblock:
Insomnia is a common complaint or disorder throughout the world. About one third of the population in the industrial countries reports difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, resulting in a non-refreshing or non-restorative sleep. The majority of the insomniacs suffer chronically from their complaints.
The maleic acid salt of Org 4420, code name Org 50081 (esmirtazapine), was selected for development in the treatment of insomnia. The first clinical trial with esmirtazapine was a proof-of-concept trial with a four-way cross-over design. All 3 esmirtazapine dose groups showed a statistically significant positive effect on Total Sleep Time (TST) (objective and subjective) and Wake Time After Sleep Onset (WASO), as compared to placebo.
The current study is a 52-week safety study in elderly outpatients with chronic primary insomnia randomized to treatment with 1.5 mg or 3.0 mg of esmirtazapine to investigate the safety and tolerability of long-term treatment with esmirtazapine in elderly patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Who Experience at Least One Adverse Event (AE)
primary_outcome.description: An AE is defined as any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of study drug, whether or not related to the study drug.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Who Discontinue Study Drug Due to an AE
primary_outcome.description: An AE is defined as any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of study drug, whether or not related to the study drug.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Alertness at Awakening
primary_outcome.description: Alertness at awakening was assessed by participants using a 0-100 mm visual analog scale (VAS) in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 6 "How did you feel upon awakening over the past 7 days?". Scores could range from 0=Tired to 100=Alert. Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using an observed cases (OC) approach.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Feeling Full of Energy
primary_outcome.description: Feeling full of energy was assessed by participants using a 0-100 mm visual analog scale (VAS) in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 7 "How full of energy have you felt over the past 7 days?". Scores could range from 0=Terribly tired to 100=Full of energy. Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using an OC approach.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Ability to Work/Function
primary_outcome.description: Ability to work/function was assessed by participants using a 0-100 mm visual analog scale (VAS) in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 8 "How were you able to work or function over the past 7 days?". Scores could range from 0=Not at all to 100=Very well. Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using an OC approach.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Total Nap Time
primary_outcome.description: Total nap time was assessed by participants in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 9a "How much time per day did you nap, on average?". Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using an OC approach.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Total Sleep Time (TST)
secondary_outcome.description: TST was defined as the time recorded by participants in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 4 "During the past 7 nights, how much time did you actually spend sleeping, on average?". Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using a last observation carried forward (LOCF) approach.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Wake Time After Sleep Onset (WASO)
secondary_outcome.description: WASO was defined as the time recorded by participants in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 4 "During the past 7 nights, how much time were you awake, on average, after falling asleep initially?" Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using a LOCF approach.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Sleep Latency (SL)
secondary_outcome.description: SL was defined as the time recorded by participants in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 4 "During the past 7 nights, how long did it take you to fall asleep, on average?" Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using a LOCF approach.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Number of Awakenings (NAW)
secondary_outcome.description: NAW was defined as the time recorded by participants in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 2a "During the past 7 nights, how many times did you wake up, on average?" Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using a LOCF approach.

clinical_study.condition: Sleep Initiation and Maintenance Disorder; Elderly

arm_group.description: Participants receive esmirtazapine 1.5 mg tablets, one tablet administered orally once daily for up to 52 weeks
Participants receive esmirtazapine 3.0 mg tablets, one tablet administered orally once daily for up to 52 weeks

outcome.title: Number of Participants Who Experience at Least One Adverse Event (AE)
outcome.description: An AE is defined as any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of study drug, whether or not related to the study drug.
outcome.population: The All-Subjects-Treated (AST) population consisted of all participants who received at least one dose of study drug.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Total Sleep Time (TST)
outcome.description: TST was defined as the time recorded by participants in response to Weekly Sleep Diary question 4 "During the past 7 nights, how much time did you actually spend sleeping, on average?". Baseline was defined as the Day 1 assessment of Days -7 to 1 before any study drug was taken. Change from Baseline was calculated using a last observation carried forward (LOCF) approach.
outcome.population: The Intent-To-Treat (ITT) population consisted of all participants who received at least one dose of study drug and had at least one postbaseline TST assessment.

reported_events.time_frame: Up to 30 days after last dose of study drug for serious AEs. Up to 7 days after last dose of study drug for non-serious AEs

group.title: Esmirtazapine 1.5 mg
group.description: Participants receive esmirtazapine 1.5 mg tablets, one tablet administered orally once daily for up to 52 weeks

group.title: Esmirtazapine 3.0 mg

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Senior Vice President, Global Clinical Development
